text:
Andrew Ng: One part of your work, is you run a 
robotics lab. If a student were to join your lab,

what is it like to show up at work in the morning?
Chelsea Finn: In the lab it's not all that

different from running machine learning 
experiments, where you run code, you try to train

a model, and then evaluate that model. There's 
also interfacing with the real robot. Oftentimes

the projects might start with the simulation and 
that might involve actually designing aspects of

the simulation, test the hypothesis you want to 
test and on the real robot there is setting up

the control stack such that you can actually 
command the robot, setting up the cameras,

collecting data, and you may want to actually 
look at the images that the robot is seeing.

Maybe visualize some of the features that your 
model has learned. It's a pretty fun process,

at least for me I think it's very rewarding 
to actually see the robot doing something

rather than just see some numbers or some 
accuracy of your model. But it also requires

persistence because robots can break down.
Andrew Ng: I used to fly autonomous helicopters so

every time a helicopter crashed 
we had to just go build a new one.

Chelsea Finn: Yea fortunately, 
arms do not crash too much.

Andrew Ng: Yes, maybe I should have 
chosen working on that instead.
